questions.question: A 50-year-old construction worker presents to the dermatology OPD with a black mole over his back as shown in the image. Which of the following investigations is the gold standard for diagnosis of this condition?
questions.explanation: lesion with irregular borders , asymmetry , and uneven distribution of colors in the lesion is suggestive of malignant melanoma . The gold standard investigation for diagnosis of melanoma is histopathological examination by a biopsy. Biopsy findings in malignant melanoma: Individual melanoma cells are usually larger than normal melanocytes or cells found in melanocytic nevi. They have enlarged nuclei with irregular contours , chromatin that is characteristically clumped at the periphery of the nuclear membrane, and prominent red (eosinophilic) nucleoli. The appearance of the tumour cells is similar in the radial and vertical phases of growth. Radial growth phase: Horizontal spread of melanoma within the epidermis & superficial dermis. Vertical growth phase: Tumor cells

questions.question: Which of the following is not included in the clinical triad of sezary syndrome?

options.C: Atypical mononuclear cells >20% of total lymphocytes

questions.explanation: sezary syndrome. It is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma presenting with boggy plaques and mucinous degeneration of hair follicles. THE TRIAD CONSISTS OF: Erythroderma: This refers to diffuse redness affecting more than 80% of the body surface area. The skin appears eczematous and may be associated with variable scaling. Sézary syndrome often presents with rapid-onset itching and erythroderma. It can occur without prior signs of another type of CTCL called mycosis fungoides. (Option A ruled out) Lymphadenopathy: Generalized enlargement of lymph nodes is a common feature. These swollen lymph nodes are often palpable and can be detected during physical examination. (Option B ruled out) Atypical Malignant (Sézary Cells): These abnormal T-cells are found in the skin, blood, and lymph nodes, comprising >20% of total lymphocyte count or total sezary count of >1000x10 9 /L. (Option C ruled out) Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th ed, page no. 140.18

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a cutaneous marker of underlying internal malignancy?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Erythema chronicum migrans Explanation: Erythema chronicum migrans (ECM) is not typically a marker of internal malignancy. It is the characteristic rash of early Lyme disease , caused by the tick-borne spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi . Erythema chronicum migrans (ECM): Occurs in about 90% of patients at the site of the tick bite . Appears 1–36 days after the bite (average: 9 days). Results from local spread of the spirochete , forming a ring-shaped lesion that enlarges at a rate of several centimeters per week . May be: Intensely erythematous or barely noticeable Flat or elevated at the center , periphery , or both Occasionally accompanied by slight scaling Target-like morphology may appear due to central clearing. Moderate burning or itching occurs in about one-third of cases. Without treatment, the lesion fades within a few weeks (range: 1 day to 14 months). Associated features may include regional lymphadenopathy and mild systemic symptoms . Necrolytic migratory erythema (Option A): Associated with : Glucagonoma (a rare pancreatic islet cell tumor). Clinical features: Extremely erythematous plaques Superficial epidermal necrosis Centrifugal spread Correctly associated with internal malignancy. Acanthosis nigricans (Option B): Can be a cutaneous marker of internal malignancy, most commonly gastric adenocarcinoma . Clinical features: Velvety, hyperpigmented plaques in skin folds (e.g., neck, axilla, groin) Also associated with insulin resistance and diabetes mellitus . Erythroderma (Option C): Defined as inflammation affecting >90% of the body surface area . Causes include: Psoriasis Malignancies : Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma > Hodgkin’s lymphoma Drugs : Phenytoin, carbamazepine, gold salts, lithium, phenylbutazone, cimetidine Inherited disorders : Ichthyosiform erythroderma, pityriasis rubra pilaris Other dermatoses : Pemphigus foliaceus, lichen planus, crusted scabies, dermatomyositis Also linked to internal malignancies , especially lymphomas

questions.question: A 50-year-old female presented with sudden eruption of asymptomatic lesions as shown in the image below. The lesions have a stuck-on appearance suggestive of a diagnosis of Seborrheic keratosis. Which of the following malignancies is commonly suspected in the given scenario?
questions.explanation: lesions is known as the sign of Leser-Trelat. It can be a symptom of paraneoplastic syndrome typically associated with gastric adenocarcinoma. However, it can also be associated with other internal malignancies. Seborrheic Keratoses (SK): Benign proliferation of keratocytes Usually seen in older age groups. Appearance - Hyperkeratotic plaques with a stuck-on appearance. Follicular plugs Sign of Leser-Trelat: The sudden appearance of seborrheic keratosis on the body reveals that there is an association with underlying GI malignancy. Treatment:

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a persistent, non-elevated, red, scaly plaque on her lower leg. The lesion has been slowly enlarging over the past several months. She reports no pain or bleeding from the lesion. Her medical history includes a solid-organ transplant five years ago, for which she is on immunosuppressive therapy.Which statement about this condition is NOT true?

options.B: HPV16 and HPV18 are commonly implicated, especially in genital lesions.
options.D: Occasionally it may undergo spontaneous partial resolution

questions.explanation: a scaly , erythematous plaque confined to the epidermis and a history of chronic sun exposure, is consistent with Bowen's disease , also known as squamous cell carcinoma in situ. The incorrect statement is that it has a high potential for invasive malignancy. Bowen's disease/Squamous cell carcinoma in situ: It is an intra-epidermal squamous cell carcinoma characterized by a persistent, non-elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a low potential for invasive malignancy. Risk factors: Arsenic exposure. Immunosuppression (organ transplant, HIV). Chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Human papilloma virus- HPV16 and HPV18 are commonly found in Bowen disease lesions, especially in anogenital areas. It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It can occur anywhere, but more in the head and neck region. Pathology: Full-thickness epidermal dysplasia & disordered differentiation with loss of epithelial polarity. The intraepidermal portion of cutaneous adnexae is generally affected. Parakeratosis and acanthosis are usually present, and keratinocytes show variable pleomorphism, nuclear hyperchromasia, and nuclear enlargement. The dermal-epidermal junction remains distinct . HPV I associated viral cytopathic changes are frequently seen particularly, but not exclusively, in lesions from genital skin. The image shows Bowen's disease- Red, erythematous plaque:

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with a slowly growing lesion on his left forearm, occasionally bleeding post-trauma, and had a lot of sun exposure throughout his life. The biopsy of the lesion is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC): SCC is a malignant tumour originating from epidermal keratinocytes, the second most common skin tumour after basal cell carcinoma (BCC). SCC is notably the most common skin tumour in immunocompromised individuals. Associated with immunocompromised states such as HIV infection and renal transplant recipients, SCC typically exhibits a lower rate of local, regional, and distant spread compared to other skin malignancies. Predisposing factors include UV exposure, immunosuppression, and conditions like xeroderma pigmentosum, albinism, LP, and DLE, which can rarely progress into SCC. Commonly presents as papules, nodules, or plaques with induration and signs of photo-damage like crusting and scaling. Histopathological examination reveals characteristic keratin pearls. Treatment: Primary treatment involves wide surgical excision with margins. Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS) aids in intraoperative histopathological examination. Advanced cases may require radiation or chemotherapy. Actinic keratosis (Option A) Actinic keratosis typically presents as rough, scaly, erythematous macules or papules on sun-exposed areas. Histologically, it is characterised by dysplastic changes confined to the epidermis without invasion into the dermis. Basal cell carcinoma (Option B): Basal cell carcinoma (BCC)

questions.question: Identify the FALSE statement among the following regarding SCC?

options.B: It occurs in sun-exposed and also over sun-protected sites including mucosa.
options.C: It is most common in transplant recipients.

questions.explanation: BCC and not SCC. SCC often presents as a scaly or crusted lesion with potential ulceration and an everted edge. Crusting and scaling are potential signs of photodamage. Squamous cell carcinoma: Basal cell carcinoma: Option A: SCC arises from keratinocytes or its appendages. Option B: SCC occurs in sun-exposed sites including mucosa. SCC can occur on sun-exposed skin such as the head, neck, and arms. Predisposing factors include UV exposure Immunocompromised individuals Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) Albinism, LP(Lichen Planus), DLE (Discoid lupus erythematosus) Option C: SCC is most common dermatological malignancy in transplant recipients due to immunosuppression. Overall, BCC is the most common skin malignancy and SCC is the second most common.

questions.question: A 65-year-old female came with complaints of a painless nodule on the right palm for the past 3 weeks. She gave a history of sustaining a thorn prick injury to the palm 4 weeks ago. On examination, the lesions appear as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: central keratinous debris is suggestive of Keratoacanthoma. Keratoacanthoma is a low-grade squamous cell cancer. It presents as a proliferating dome-shaped keratin-filled crater. Patients usually give a prior history of minor trauma. M/C Site- Face > hands Phases of growth- Growth, Maturation, Resolution phase It starts as a papule. Develops to a dome-shaped nodule with a central keratin plug. Outer epidermal lining everts to surrounding skin Plug falls off. Lesion disappears. The treatment of choice is an excisional procedure with 4mm margins. Option B : Bowen's disease appears histologically as SCC in situ. It initially presents as a reddened area that progresses to thickened plaque and may vary from a small lesion to a large area. It forms an adherent crust with no bleeding points. When it is confined to the glans penis or vulva, Bowen's disease is referred to as Erythroplasia of Queyrat. Management includes photodynamic therapy, imiquimod, and 5-FU. Option C: Mycosis Fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, and plaque-like lesions are seen. Option D : Actinic keratosis consists of hyperkeratotic erythematous papules and patches on the sun-exposed skin. The lower lip is the common site of the lesion. It has some potential for malignant transformation. Papules with rough scaly surfaces. An adherent

questions.question: Which among the following is false regarding Marjolin’s Ulcer?

options.A: It has a tendency to convert into SCC and BCC.
options.B: It doesn’t commonly have lymphatic spread.
options.D: It occurs within a few days of surgery.

questions.explanation: Marjolin’s ulcer, which develops from a scar, takes a long time to form. Marjolin’s ulcer: Marjolin’s ulcer commonly develops in burn scars, venous ulcers, and osteomyelitis sinuses. SCC > BCC conversion. Appearance: Raised everted cauliflower-like edges are seen over the scar. Lymphatic spread is rarely seen due to scarring and poor blood supply. Treatment: Wide local excision. Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th ed, page no.124.5

questions.question: A 65-year-old female presented with a slow-growing, painless lesion on her face that has been present for several months. Physical examination reveals an ulcerated lesion with rolled borders and telangiectasias. The lesion is non-tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: slow-growing, locally invasive tumor and it rarely metastasizes. It arises from pluripotent cells within the basal layer of the epidermis or follicular structures. Clinical Features It presents initially small, scaly plaque Slow progressive course of peripheral extension Develops into nodular-ulcerative lesions, it has a thread-like margin, telangiectasia and it bleeds on touch. Site: Face, Around eyes, Nose Histopathology: peripheral palisading of tumour cells (shown in the image), the cells resemble cells of stratum basale that have grown into the dermis. This cluster of cells is surrounded at the periphery by perpendicularly arranged cells . It also has a well-organized stroma surrounding it. Treatment Medical: Imiquimod, 5-FU,Intralesional interferon α -2b Hedgehog pathway inhibitors:(Vismodegib) Surgical: Mohs micrographic surgery, Done in recurrent BCCs. Option A: Squamous cell carcinoma Clinical Features: There is a presence of a papule, nodule, or plaque with induration, accompanied by signs of photodamage such as crusting and scaling. Histopathology: Keratin pearls. Option C: Malignant melanoma: The image presented above doesn’t meet the diagnostic criteria of malignant melanoma (ABCDE)

questions.question: A 38-year-old female presents with an increasing size of a mole. A lesion with irregular borders and variegated colours is noted, histopathologically confirmed as atypical melanocytes invading the dermis. Which nevus type is most commonly associated with malignant transformation to melanoma?
questions.explanation: 20cm ( giant congenital melanocytic nevus ), have a much higher risk of developing melanoma over the individual's lifetime, particularly if they are larger or have a nodular component. Option A: Dermal nevus are typically benign and are less likely to transform into melanoma compared to congenital melanocytic nevi. Option B: Compound nevus have Nevus cells in both dermis and epidermis. They have a slight risk of malignant transformation but are not as high as in large congenital melanocytic nevus. Option D: Becker's nevus is a benign cutaneous hamartoma that is usually not associated with malignant transformation. Types of Nevi:

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman with fair skin and a history of teenage sunburns presents with a mole on her upper back that has become larger and darker over the past few months. The lesion is pigmented with irregular borders, color variation, asymmetry, slight elevation, and measures 1.5 cm in diameter. She reports occasional itching and tenderness but denies bleeding or ulceration. Identify the true statements regarding this condition. The most common type is nodular melanoma. CDKN2A mutation is most commonly involved in sporadic melanoma. Depth > 6 mm is suggestive of melanoma. Clark’s classification is used in malignant melanoma. Interferon- I can be used for the prevention of metastasis.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 4,5 Explanation: 1. Nodular melanoma (False): Superficial spreading is the most common type. 2. CDKN2A (False): BRAF mutation is more common in sporadic melanoma. 3. Depth >6 mm (False): >6 mm size raises suspicion, but Breslow depth is for staging. 4. Clark’s classification (True): Used for assessing melanoma invasion depth. 5. Interferon- α (True): Used as adjuvant therapy to prevent metastasis in high-risk melanoma. Types of melanoma: Type Site Description Superficial spreading (M/C type) Any (more common on the upper back and, in women, lower legs) Brown mixed with bluish-red, bluish-black, reddish brown, and often whitish pink. The lesion border is often visibly and/or palpably raised Lentigo maligna Sun-exposed surfaces, particularly malar region and temple In flat portions, brown and tan predominate, but whitish grey sometimes present; in nodules, reddish brown, bluish grey, bluish-black. Acral lentiginous Palm, sole, nail bed, mucous membrane In flat portions, dark brown; in raised lesions (plaques), brown-black or blue-black. Nodular Any Reddish blue, purple, or bluish-black; can be uniform or mixed with brown and black. Investigations: Clinical examination. Genetics: Mutations in genes such as BRAF, NRAS, and NF1 are common in sporadic melanoma, driving tumor progression through the MAPK pathway Dermoscopy. Biopsy. Immunohistochemistry: The markers are S-100, HMB-45 (the most specific), Melan-A (MART-1), and MITF. CT scan. Breslow’s and Clarke’s Classifications of Malignant Melanoma: Stage Classification Clarke Breslow I Involvement of epidermis ≤ 0.75 mm II Involvement of epidermis + dermis 0.76-1.5 mm III Involvement of dermal papillae 1.5-4 mm IV Involvement of reticular dermis >4 mm V Involvement of subcutaneous tissue - Management: Wide local excision (with margins measured before excision and determined by Breslow depth, sentinel lymph node biopsy indicated for tumours with a depth of >1.0 mm). If the tumour is aggressive: Immunotherapy. Chemotherapy. Targeted

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with a slow-growing lesion on the face as shown in the image. What is the best indicator for the prognosis of this condition?
questions.explanation: factor for melanoma. It is the distance in millimetres (mm) between the epidermal granular layer and the primary lesion's deepest level of invasion. Thicker tumours have a higher metastatic potential. The prognosis of primary melanoma depends on several factors: Tumour thickness (Breslow Depth) : Thicker tumours are associated with poor prognosis. Ulceration : It is another important independent poor prognostic factor. Even in locally advanced melanoma, primary tumour ulceration retains its significance. Mitotic Rate: Higher mitotic rates are associated with a worse prognosis. Sentinel Lymph Node Status: Lymph node involvement indicates a higher risk of metastasis and poorer outcome. Other Clinicopathologic Factors: LDH levels, tumor location, and genetic mutations Tumor size (Option B) – While larger tumors may indicate more advanced disease, size alone is not as

questions.question: A 52-year-old male has a slow-growing, scaly, reddish patch on his lower back that has become a thickened plaque over several months. He reports no itching, pain, or discomfort. Examination reveals similar plaques on his abdomen. A biopsy shows a monoclonal proliferation of CD4+/CD45R0+ helper T cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: lymphoma is Mycosis Fungoides. Mycosis Fungoides Monoclonal proliferation of predominantly CD4+/CD45R0+ helper T cells and the loss of mature T-cell antigens in the skin and other involved organs. Slow-growing and higher chances of metastasis Site : Girdle (abdomen, back) Clinical Features: Polymorphic Starts as a scaly macule. Turns into erythematous plaque Progresses into tumor/nodular stage Ends up as erythroderma. Progression of mycosis fungoides: Patch stage -------------->Plague stage------------------>Tumor stage Histopathology: Epidermotropism: Invasion of the epidermis with T-cells Pautrier's microabscess - Collection of T-cells Treatment: Patch stage: Topical steroids, Nitrogen mustard, Carmustine, PUVA, UVB Plaque stage Total skin electron beam therapy (TOC) Interferon-alpha Oral retinoids Nodal and visceral type CHOP regimen C yclophosphamide D oxorubicin hydrochloride (h ydroxy daunomycin) V incristine sulfate ( O ncovin) P rednisolone Extracorporeal photophoresis can be used as systemic therapy for mycosis fungoides. Option A: Unlike mycosis fungoides, sezary syndrome does not typically present with a progression from macules to plaques and tumors. It is a severe form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma with a poor prognosis. The triad includes, I Erythroderma Lymphadenopathy Atypical malignant Sézary cells in the skin, blood, and lymph nodes. Option B: Psoriasis typically presents with well-defined, scaly plaques, primarily on extensor surfaces rather than the girdle area. It does not follow the polymorphic progression seen in Mycosis fungoides. Option C: Basal cell carcinoma usually presents as a pearly nodular lesion with a rolled border, not a polymorphic progression from macule to plaque to tumor. It is also less likely to present with widespread erythroderma.

questions.question: A 25-year-old homosexual male presents with the following lesion on his legs which have progressed in size. Which of the following is the most common organism associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: lesions coalescing with each other, which is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma . Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm. It is the most common cancer seen in HIV patients. Kaposi sarcoma caused by HHV-8 stimulates VEGF and inhibits p53 leading to malignancy. All forms of Kaposi sarcoma are associated with HHV-8 infection as an etiological agent. Types of Kaposi sarcoma: Classic (Meditteranean) Endemic African ( HIV negative ) Transplant associated AIDS-associated Epidemic KS HHV8 associated diseases: Kaposi’s Sarcoma: Primary Effusion Lymphoma (PEL) : PEL is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by the accumulation of fluid in body cavities. Multicentric Castleman Disease (MCD) : MCD is a rare lymphoproliferative disorder. Kaposi's Sarcoma of mouth due to HHV8: Option A: HHV-4 Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) Most common human viruses, spread primarily through saliva and bodily fluids. Infections- Infectious mononucleosis Lymphoproliferative
